sentences.sentence: 'Perfect storm' notjust on energy frontYour editorial "Time for a realistic net zero plan" (June 6) is easily the best exposition that I have read on the "perfect storm" that we face with the spike in energy prices and the perils confronting us on the twisting pathway to net zero emissions.We could add to Alexander Downer's opinion article, "Liberals must fight back to win the battle of values" (June 6), the vexed issue of private health insurance, which people are abandoning in droves because it does not represent value for money.With the blowout in elective surgery waiting lists in public hospitals - some people are waiting for years for a hip replacement - the role of private health will be critical in tackling the seemingly endless backlog of patients requiring necessary, life-improving operations.Randal MarkeyCampbell, ACTLet's not forget theongoing COVID-19 tollYour editorial "Gas-fired baptism for a new cabinet with much to do" (June 4-5) presents an accurate picture of the landscape facing the Albanese government in its first term.

However, it omits to factor in the cost and disruption of COVID-19 and influenza.COVID-related deaths this year have already outnumbered the fatalities since the epidemic began in 2020 and the daily infection rate means nearly 100,000 people going into a seven-day isolation period.
That means at any given time almost 700,000 people are out of the workforce.
That's without counting the disruption from what is being predicted as the worst flu season we've had for a while.The health system is already reeling from fatigue.

We, as a nation, have to all muck in as best we can and start working towards solutions.John MosigKew, VicFocus on productivitycould start with myGovBill Shorten's call for an audit of myGov is timely.
As part of the changes to the export grant scheme initiated by the Morrison government, eligible exporters must re-register with Austrade using a myGov ID.

As many exporters use a variety of legal structures including trusts, this has been a frustrating experience.Countless hours have been lost ensuring that the identity of the nominated representative is linked to an ATO portal.
Should that representative leave the exporter, the procedure must be re-initiated.
All for an export grant rebate that has decreased by more than 70 per cent.Many have given up.

The time and complexity involved in the new process does not justify the return.The Albanese government needs to have a searing focus on productivity if we are to successfully transition from a fossil-fuel-driven export economy.

MyGov is a good place to start.Warren CrossSydney, NSWThe royals representa worthy continuityAndrew Marr ("How the Queen's sense of duty prevailed in an age of individualism", June 3) believes monarchy is expensive and embarrassing.
Yet every day, in capitalist democracies, people are born into influence and wealth.
Witness how certain families and cliques call the shots in various spheres.The royals may not wield political power, but they are in demand, and carry out duties and roles.
The Windsors provide a link to a centuries-long system of governance.

Democratic systems still have a long, long way to go before proving themselves similarly adept at continuity.David WeberNorth Fremantle, WAACT stood out inbacking a republicIt is wrong to claim that "no state or territory" voted in favour of the republic in 1999 ("The minister tasked with removing the Crown", June 3).
The ACT voted 63 per cent in favour.John HawkinsUniversity of Canberra

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: 'Perfect storm' notjust on energy frontYour editorial "Time for a realistic net zero plan" (June 6) is easily the best exposition that I have read on the "perfect storm" that we face with the spike in energy prices and the perils confronting us on the twisting pathway to net zero emissions.We could add to Alexander Downer's opinion article, "Liberals must fight back to win the battle of values" (June 6), the vexed issue of private health insurance, which people are abandoning in droves because it does not represent value for money.With the blowout in elective surgery waiting lists in public hospitals - some people are waiting for years for a hip replacement - the role of private health will be critical in tackling the seemingly endless backlog of patients requiring necessary, life-improving operations.Randal MarkeyCampbell, ACTLet's not forget theongoing COVID-19 tollYour editorial "Gas-fired baptism for a new cabinet with much to do" (June 4-5) presents an accurate picture of the landscape facing the Albanese government in its first term. However, it omits to factor in the cost and disruption of COVID-19 and influenza.COVID-related deaths this year have already outnumbered the fatalities since the epidemic began in 2020 and the daily infection rate means nearly 100,000 people going into a seven-day isolation period. That means at any given time almost 700,000 people are out of the workforce. That's without counting the disruption from what is being predicted as the worst flu season we've had for a while.The health system is already reeling from fatigue. We, as a nation, have to all muck in as best we can and start working towards solutions.John MosigKew, VicFocus on productivitycould start with myGovBill Shorten's call for an audit of myGov is timely. As part of the changes to the export grant scheme initiated by the Morrison government, eligible exporters must re-register with Austrade using a myGov ID. As many exporters use a variety of legal structures including trusts, this has been a frustrating experience.Countless hours have been lost ensuring that the identity of the nominated representative is linked to an ATO portal. Should that representative leave the exporter, the procedure must be re-initiated. All for an export grant rebate that has decreased by more than 70 per cent.Many have given up. The time and complexity involved in the new process does not justify the return.The Albanese government needs to have a searing focus on productivity if we are to successfully transition from a fossil-fuel-driven export economy. MyGov is a good place to start.Warren CrossSydney, NSWThe royals representa worthy continuityAndrew Marr ("How the Queen's sense of duty prevailed in an age of individualism", June 3) believes monarchy is expensive and embarrassing. Yet every day, in capitalist democracies, people are born into influence and wealth. Witness how certain families and cliques call the shots in various spheres.The royals may not wield political power, but they are in demand, and carry out duties and roles. The Windsors provide a link to a centuries-long system of governance. Democratic systems still have a long, long way to go before proving themselves similarly adept at continuity.David WeberNorth Fremantle, WAACT stood out inbacking a republicIt is wrong to claim that "no state or territory" voted in favour of the republic in 1999 ("The minister tasked with removing the Crown", June 3). The ACT voted 63 per cent in favour.John HawkinsUniversity of Canberra
